subject: physics
title: Newton's Laws of Motion
description: Learn about the three fundamental laws governing motion through interactive 3D models and guided lab steps.

labSteps.title: First Law – Inertia
labSteps.instruction: Observe how an object at rest stays at rest unless acted upon by a net external force. Tap the stationary block.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: The block remains still until a force is applied.

labSteps.title: Second Law – F=ma
labSteps.instruction: Drag the force arrow to apply different magnitudes. Notice how acceleration changes with force.

labSteps.title: Third Law – Action-Reaction
labSteps.instruction: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Observe the rocket exhaust pushing down as the rocket goes up.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Both action and reaction forces are equal in magnitude.

labSteps.title: Applying the Laws
labSteps.instruction: Rotate the scene to see all three laws in action simultaneously. Observe the combined system.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: All three laws apply simultaneously in every physical interaction.

questions.question: What does Newton's First Law describe?
questions.explanation: The First Law states that objects at rest stay at rest and objects in motion stay in motion unless acted upon by an external force — this property is called inertia.

questions.question: F = ma represents which of Newton's Laws?
questions.explanation: F = ma is the mathematical form of Newton's Second Law: force equals mass times acceleration.

questions.question: If you push a wall, the wall pushes back with equal force. This is Newton's:
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law states that for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.

questions.question: A 5 kg object accelerates at 3 m/s². What net force is acting on it?
questions.explanation: Using F = ma: F = 5 kg × 3 m/s² = 15 N.
